title.narrative: By the end of 2020, the number, capacity, engagement, and level of cooperation of local civil society anti-torture actors around the world has increased and strengthened, achieving progress toward targeted results through engagement with the OMCT in focus

Greater compliance with the UN Convention Against Torture in focus countries, demonstrated through achievement of country- and/or regional/international targeted results toward the project objectives during the period. 1) Number and impact of major campaigns (global or regional), including in 15-20 focus countries and/or regions will take place to revive and reemphasize the absolute prohibition of torture as a basic human right; 2) Effectiveness of actors (country, region, international agencies) actively engaged in advocacy in reducing the gap between CAT recommendations and implementations.
The OMCT’s ‘focus countries’ in 2019-2020 include: Afghanistan; Bangladesh; Benin; Brazil; Cameroon; Cuba; the DRC; Ethiopia; Guatemala; Honduras; India; Indonesia; Ivory Coast; Kyrgyzstan; Mexico; Niger; Pakistan; Philippines; the Russian Federation; Tajikistan; Togo; Turkey; Uruguay; Uzbekistan; and Venezuela.

target.value: End-line indicators 2020: • OMCT engaged actively with 150 OMCT members and partners in their fight against torture in 80 countries. • OMCT protected and strengthened 75-100 members and partners, enabling them to continue their work. • Achievement 2020: 17 targeted results.

actual.value: End-line indicators 2020: • 5 new Network Members joined in 2020. • OMCT engaged actively with 118 OMCT members and partners in their fight against torture in 87 countries.

• 1 advance that focus on or affect a specific vulnerable population were achieved in legislation/policy (2020); • 8 high-impact pieces of media attention on the special vulnerability of children/women/migrants/minorities to torture and ill treatment were published in national and/or international media (2020); • 1 steps taken in focus countries towards greater accountability for abuses, such as indictments or legal judgments sanctioning abuse (2020) (Philippines).

• 2 advances or defences that focus on or affect a specific vulnerable population were achieved in legislation/policy (2019) (Togo, Philippines); • 2 high-impact pieces of media attention on the special vulnerability of children to torture and ill treatment published in national and/or international media (2019) (Philippines, Brazil); • 0 steps taken in focus countries towards greater accountability for abuses, such as indictments or legal judgments sanctioning abuse (2019).
